Japanese Tea Garden.name: Japanese Tea Garden

address.streetAddress: Golden Gate Park 75 Hagiwara Tea Garden Dr.

reviews: Nice photo-ops/peaceful walk within Golden Gate Park

Great spot for photos within Golden Gate Park. Peaceful area for a short walk or tea break. Park’s Shakespeare and Botanical Gardens are in same area. Admission fee to enter.

Note: Parking appeared very crowded on the Sunday I visited. Luckily light rail was easy from Union Square area/Powell station. I was able to stop @ GG Park and then continue along light rail route to Haight-Ashbury area. Great directions and transit options are easy to find using your smartphone.

Show less
Google the address. Trip advisor may still be wrong
This is gorgeous. Go and drink tea because it's 6 bucks but worth it. Koi swim around and they're little waterfalls and bridges. It cost 9 dollars to enter and take all the pictures.

We visited the gardens with friends, all with children under the age of 10, while waiting for the next door museum to open.

The gardens charge an entrance fee, unless you are a resident of San Francisco. If you have a proof that you are local - do not forget to bring it.
The garden itself is relatively small and you do need more than 1/2 hour to see it. It is self guided, but you can also choose to go on an organized tour. There are free walking tours on Monday mornings that won’t charge you even the entrance fees.
There is a small cafe and a gift shop inside.
Show less
A Small but Beautiful Tea Garden

I would recommend you stop and visit this Tea Garden. It's small and easy to walk in less than 1 hour. Beautifully designed and well maintained, it is a peaceful, tranquil area. This is my second time to visit and I was here again on 02/18/18.
Show less
Do not miss this lovely garden hidden in the Golden Gate Park. Very lovely and peaceful even when crowded.
I come here to chill, to relax. Amazing space, empty & crowded, boring & breathtaking. Always bring visitors when they’re in the City, they love it. Enjoy!

Visited the garden today and it was beautiful. So peaceful. The service at the concession was polite and kind. I’m glad it was as it took a long time to find it. Used the map from Trip advisor site and it took me to the wrong place. I found my self over 3 miles away. Then their was no actual address on trip advisor so when I finally got to Golden gate park I was a mile away from the garden.
Show less

These gardens are pretty and peaceful. However I am glad I had looked at tips before I went so that we got in for free, as I think for a family of 4 it would be quite pricey for a fairly small area. (It is free to get in before 10am on a Wednesday)
Show less

Beautiful place to spend an hour or so. It is quiet small so I can imagine it being crowded at peak times.
There is a small entrance fee but I felt it was well worth it.
There is a small gift shop where items were reasonably priced.
There is also a small cafe, the food and tea was lovely and service was super fast.
Show less
The photos here are amazing. It was great to take in all of the wonderful sights I was totally in awe. Great to check out and then visit golden gate park when you leave!!
Very relaxing and peaceful. Good for families but $9\piece to get in. Paths throughout to check out different areas inside.
Peaceful Japanese spot in the heart of SFO

Under my bucket list n' I've done it Jan 2013. Coming from a very far Mediterranean city Algiers, visiting SFO, Golden Gate Park & Japanese tea garden have been a must see. Well I've decided to really take advantage of my Californian Business trip so I've picked the Fri before 10 a.m. Free entrance, I did enjoy self guiding my self across the Garden, this typically extreme orient environment is enchanting. You really cut off with the noisy city. It's so much impressive to understand that this place has been dedicated for People from Asia and Japan in particular as a tribute for WW2 common heritage.
Show less
A beautiful garden but the main pond was empty when we were there, which was a shame. it's $9 to get in and you really spend more than an hour there can
That bridge is a lot steeper than I thought!

I was very happy I was able to visit the tea garden and to see the foliage, fish, and fun! There is a lot of character and serenity throughout the area as well as a great deal of history and fun facts starting with the how the front gate was constructed. The gift shop area was also interesting if for no other reason than its eerily accurate fortune. My only critique is one that can't really be helped and it's that sometimes peace is hard to find inside a crowd of people but I will just have to try back on a less busy day!
Show less
This garden is so peaceful and charming. We really enjoyed our time there beacuse the nature is so wonderful, and all those little bridges inside. It's all about zen.

This place is so tiny and not worth $9.00. When I look on the site I thought it was $6.00 and that what I wrote down. Turns out if you don't live in San Francisco then you pay $9.00. If you are into Tea I guess this place would be nice. I did pick up some nick nack in the shop.
Show less
Enjoyable walk through a lush garden

We enjoyed walking through this lush garden with very interesting structures in Golden Gate Park. I don't think it is worth the full admission price of $9, but kids and seniors prices are lower. Also, the best deal, admission is free on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday if you arrive between the 9:00 am opening and 10:00 am.
Show less

Easy access to visit this place. The fee to visit to the park is not to significant but the park is pretty small. I enjoyed afternoon Japanese green tea with Mochi , a perfect combination and very pretty - instagramable. The attractions are not to many, but it's a great park to take an afternoon break in town. Very green indeed.
Show less
I love the the beauty of this garden. If you have time worth seeing if you are in the Golden Gate Park Area.
A truly beautiful Japanese garden. Try to visit when it is quiet and you can take advantage of its contemplative power.
There's so much more here than one would expect. I spent years in Japan, and they have captured the essence of Japanese gardens. And the round bridge is fun!
Picturesque and the perfect way to spend time. Great pictures and ambiance. Not to busy during February, we went on a weekday. Golden gate park is breathtaking.
A must see when visiting SF! Absolutely gorgeous! Beautiful garden very well kept, full of Japanese treasures!

Cute tea garden. I thought it was very small though. We took our time and walked slow and took some pictures and the whole thing maybe took an hour. 9 dollars for adults. If you have never been to a tea garden it’s worth the stop.
Show less
Tranquil but not sure it fully justifies the $9 fee

Yes there is a 'hefty' $9 each entry fee but when we visited in October it was peaceful and the tranquility was just what we needed after a very full day of sight seeing.
The arched Moon Bridge is stunning, the bronze Buddha is the largest outside of Asia, the gardens, temples, the zen Rock garden....allow yourself to slow down, forget the entry fee, yes it's small, so take your time, go around again, enjoy, absorb the tranquility.
Show less
Save your money if you're british
$9 for a garden not much bigger than an English back garden. A disappointment & rip off. Particularly as every feature garden or glass house in the park has the same admission charge,
If you have never seen one and do not mind the $9 ticket, go in. It is small, can be crowded, and does not represent the true beauty of the Japanese gardens.
Beautiful gardens and architecture A delightful place to stroll, have a cup of tea and some great tea cookies.

At $9 per adult, based on its size and offerings, it would make much more sense at perhaps $4-$5. While interesting, it is quite small and underwhelming when compared to other tea gardens that I have visited. While Golden Gate Park is fabulous, I would spend my time and money on other attractions within the park.
Show less
Great spot for beautiful photos!! I am not into botany, but it was a quick 20 minutes and new experience

If you are already in the Golden Gate park or near the science center, botanical garden, or modern art museum then the Japanese Garden is an easy stop.

We went for a new experience. I had never been to a Japanese Garden before nor I am particually into plants.

However, I do appreciate beautiful photos and I got lots of those.

The price did not bother me.
Show less
Nice oasis in the middle of a big city

Loved it here! Even though it was "winter". It was very interesting and relaxing. Very clean and beautiful garden. Lots of things to explore in the nature. The little restaurant inside the garden was ok. Good polite service, however maybe a little overpriced. Food ( I at least thought so ) was typical Japanese.
Definitely recommend it - would love to see this place during spring or fall!!
Show less
This was a calming and peaceful way to spend a good part of the day, enjoying this gorgeously landscaped garden.
Nice place to relax mind and body

Inside the Golden gate park adjacent to the botanical garden this is a great place to wander around lush green garden with flowers and rare plants / trees. The great Buddha statue was very blissful to admire. There is a guide that walks thru if you are interested to understand the historic nature of this place. Don’t miss this. There is a real Japanese tea store as well. Kids will enjoy as well walking around water, small bridges etc.
Show less
We have always enjoyed visiting this garden. My wife has many varieties of Japanese maple trees so she spends way to much time here admiring the trees.
The scenery was beautiful. Very quiet and serene, and well kept. The tea house was crowded, and was smaller than expected.
As you enter you have a good idea of what the whole place will show you, expensive cup of tea if you have a family

The Japanese Tea Garden takes you out of the city and into a natural, living garden of Japanese maples, bamboos, and other plantings. The brass sculptures of birds in the waterway are lovely and a calm resides here that everyone would enjoy. Sit, listen, breathe, and enjoy!
Show less

My purse was stolen while drinking tea here. I had sat down with my purse by my right foot, looked away for about 5 minutes while I was served tea, and when I got up to leave it was gone. My wallet, its contents and my phone were in it. Please look out for your belongings here.
Show less
It is good small garden in the golden gate park. It should have been a five star but i gave 4 star as it is over priced. 9$+ per head. It takes maximum 20 mins to cover the entire area.
Free before 10am M/W/F! There is a nice koi pond, a little gift shop, and amazing scenery to go around! I was there before 10am and it wasn't very crowded so the mornings are a must!
Pretty park with Bonsai and Japanese tea place and shop
Need to pay an entrance fee. Park is well maintained and has a Japanese tea place and shop. Worth stopping for tea or light meal.

Having visited Japan previously on three occasions and having seen my fair share of gardens there, I'm comfortable stating that this is as good as any you would find in Japan.

It's not overly large, but what it lacks in size, it makes up for in authenticity and beauty.

Definitely a worthwhile visit if you want to escape to Japan for a few hours.
Show less
for such a small garden area - entry cost was way too much and even the cafe is over priced - not so worth at all
This was a nice peaceful place with interesting tours about the history running. My family enjoyed walking around here.
Beautiful and serene space tucked in Golden Gate Park

I love coming here. Protip: Get there early on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays: free admission before 10am.

It's nice to just walk around and take a break from the hustle and bustle of the nearby CA Academy of Sciences and De Young Museum. Lots of cool photo opportunities too if that's your thing. Climb the bridge!
Show less

If you have been to other Japanese Tea Gardens, I would suggest that you save your time and money by not going to this one. There is a lovely garden in Saratoga that is free. (At least, it was when we visited).
A beautiful garden hidden in the middle of Golden Gate Park. Work dropping by. YOu probably need an hour to enjoy it leisurely, a little longer if you want to stop to enjoy some of their tea!
Small garden set with the Japanese touch. Quiet place if you come early. Free entrance before 10:00 a.m on Mon, Wed an Fri.

A lovely garden with many facets right next to the Art Centre and cafe. Not a large garden but beautiful. The arched bridge is a feature and steep to climb. early morning or later in the day is the best time to visit so that there are not too many people there.
Show less
A tranquil break from running around
The Japanese Tea garden is a great place to slow down and listen to the tinkle of water in a stream and admire the beauty of the place

Open your mind as you close your eyes and just breath. This is what this place encourages you to do as you walk its garden paths. Very relaxing and inspirational!. The grounds are well kept. Get away from the hustle and bustle of the city and come fere for some "ME" time.
Show less

After a rather noisy few hours in the Science Museum this was a much needed break. Quiet paths, lovely landscaping, and it was a beautiful day. Stop at the little restaurant for a light snack and some tea.

Very pretty but way too small, especially for the cost of admission. The miso soup at the restaurant was good, but the strawberry mochi mini dessert was excellent. We were dissappointed in the restrooms, had to wait due to only three stalls.
Beautiful but very busy and noisy

There is an entrance fee to visit the garden. It's very beautiful but it was very busy and noisy the day we visited. There is a small tea cafe and a gift shop that was nice. I wouldn't say this is a must see but if you enjoy visiting various gardens, it is beautiful.
Show less
Had a lovely trip to the Japanese tea gardens very peaceful and tranquil but at $9 each found it expensive.
Pretty but not really worth the price of admission. It is self guided, with no maps, contained in a small area.

We went before 10:00 on a Wednesday, so it was free (and busy) and we really enjoyed it. There are fun architectural features, and lots of appealing little paths. The wooden arch bridge is really fun and you're allowed to walk over it (unlike the one in the Huntington Library). We spent about an hour there. Fun time!
Show less
Don't go out of your way

Having visited San Francisco before, we have done most of the major tourist attractions, and thought we’d do something new. I found this a disappointment . There’s very little signage to give you a sense of what plants were there – just a few explaining objects in the garden (I honestly can’t remember what they were) . If you are already out there and can get in in time for the free admission, it’s a pleasant 20-minute experience. But at $12 a person, I would have expected more. If you want to see something impressive, go to the nearby botanical gardens.
Show less
You will love the garden as I did but the garden is too small for the expensive entry price. You can take about 30 minutes to complete the whole thing with slow walking.
It reminded me of many of the gardens that I've visited in Japan. Very authentic, peaceful, and well done.
Beautiful but not really authentic Japanese garden

Entrance area seems typical Japanese garden. I would say that most of gardening structure are done by Japanese way. But when you walk further inside of the garden, there are Chinese style of gate and a building which distract nice Japanese atmosphere. I was shocked to see them there. It is small garden. Not like other big cities' Japanese garden I've seen.
Show less
very nice garden to visit at the golden gate park, well kept, good atmosphere, easy for kids as well, bus stop just off the entrance
These are beautiful walled gardens that do require an entry fee. There are exceptions so I suggest you check online before you visit. Beautiful. 1977

Buy the 9$ ticket and go! Great place to unwind and enjoy a peaceful walk around the gardens. Cool plants, waterways and architecture. Spend about an hour at this location and it was about right. If you are at the golden gate park, visit the gardens. You will be glad you did.
Show less

It’s a smaller place located in the Golden Gate Park. You won’t spend more than an hour here, but it is pretty for a little stroll. There’s a small tea house on site where you can get fortune and almond cookies, udon soup, edamame, matcha ice cream and of course tea.
Show less

I went early and it was not very busy, which made my experience even more enjoyable, since it was so serene. A great place to chill out; had some great tea at the cafe. Very picturesque; bring a camera.
An oasis in the heart of the city
This is a very serene area that is a must see if you like Japanese gardens. We had the most peaceful walk and admired the zen of the expansive gardens.
A NICE WAY TO SPEND A AFTERNOON
IF you want to relax and take it easy after a trip around golden gate park this place is a must visit, great staff great tea and food, chill out

I was here in the fall and it was beautiful. I imagine it is probably nice year-round. I didn't have any, but there is a teahouse where you can purchase Japanese tea. My only negative is that I think the price is a bit high, but this is San Francisco.
Show less

This green oasis in Golden Gate Park is near the DeYoung Museum of Art. In addition to a tea room/patio, a gift shop, numerous paths for a calming walks, several Japanese buildings, you have a slew of photo opportunities. TIP - if you go early on certain days (check their website), there is free admission for the first hour.
Show less
My favourite part of Golden Gate Park
Such a beauty little oasis with fantastic food and tea as well as gorgeous scenery and plant life. Would absolutely go back
Lots of photo opportunities and relaxing streams - with some beautiful Koi Carp - OK for a quick dose of peace and quiet.
One can visit this garden to see Japanese horticulture. One can see plenty of tea plantations alongwith other plants.
One of my favorite places on earth.
The Japanese Tea Garden is charming and fun. We could spend hours wandering. The tea and finger sandwiches are always yummy. It's a must stop every time we visit the city.
This place sure was relaxing. A nice walk through the gardens really calmed us down. Get yourself some food and tea's before you leave.

We stopped by when we got off the bus tour.Its a very pretty well maintained garden with great photo opportunities. We were a bit disappointed with the Tea House, thought there could have been a better selection of food as we were there for lunch. But it was a nice way to spend a couple of hours.
Show less

This beautiful Japanese garden is well worth a visit if you have time. The best way to get there is by tour bus. It is the most serene place with stunning plants, water features and statues. I could literally have spent hours here just relaxing. It is ideal for getting away from the hustle and bustle of the city and just recharging your batteries. Lovely to walk around and not expensive to get in.
Show less

It costs about $9 per person. Yes, its a bit pricy, but the effort that goes into the garden you have to appreciate. Visiting the garden can take anywhere between 30 minutes to 2 hours. It is a very calm place.

This is a very pretty garden, although we were disappointed it wasn’t larger, after taking public transportation all across the city. The high arching drum bridge was lovely, the pagodas were beautiful but looking like it’s time to do some renovations to help preserve them. We’ve seen many in China, and it’s heartbreaking to see them in various states of decay.
The zen garden was quite unique, loved it!
Lovely tea house and gift shop.

This is a very small garden also normal garden nothing special,for couples it is good they can spend time ,sea view also good no public transfer is there

Trip advisor reviews prompted our visit to The Japanese Tea Gardens and it was amazing. The gardens are beautifully laid out, incredibly tranquil and a lovely place to be, right in the middle of San Francisco. It's by far the stand out place we visited in our four days in San Francisco.
Show less
We came on a tip from a friend. It used to be free but now it costs $9 a person for adults. It's nice, serene but small. Not sure it's worth the entrance fee but still a nice place.

I love the Japanese Tea Garden. It is a beautiful and calming respite from the hustle and bustle of the Academy of Sciences. Enjoying a lovely cup of tea and the snack mix reminds me of visiting the tea garden with my grandmother as a girl. On this past trip we were lucky enough to watch a raccoon family climbing up and down a big tree for about 20 minutes. Very entertaining!
Show less

We throughly enjoyed walking amongst the manicured and quite aged gardens and temples. This garden is truly a gem to the American People and I highly recommend attending. We strolled about the garden and then enjoyed a lovely pot of tea at the cafe, just relaxing and enjoying the serenity the beautiful landscaping provides.
Show less

This was a "must" visit for us whilst in SF.
Golden Gate Park itself is interesting and diverting, with loads to see and do but it is worth paying the extra to go into the Japanese Tea Garden.
The whole effect is calming and tranquil and well laid out. Take time to explore all the different areas, it's fab.
Dare one almost say it is romantic? :-)

Enjoy the place. In a October is everything is beautiful . You can visit this place with friends, family or solo

I did quite enjoy my walk around these gardens, but compared to some other Japanese Tea Gardens I've been too was a bit underwhelmed. I was hoping for a few more areas to sit and enjoy the view, but the crowds made it hard. Still lovely and good for a little explore if you're in the area.
Show less

If you are in the area, the Japanese Tea Garden is well worth the visit. We paid $9 per person and spent about an hour touring. We visited on a weekday before lunch and the Garden was not packed with people - we were told that it does get busy at peak times. The Gardens are well maintained although a bit smaller than we had anticipated...not a negative, but don't expect the Gardens to be extensive. Very nice!
Show less
Expensive like the whole San Francisco
$18 to get in so quite expensive place but so is the whole San Francisco. The place itself is very nice. Check the pictures!
Lovely and Relaxing. Pleasant and Fun

Give yourself at least two hours to stroll through the gardens and gift shop. I might even suggest three, which will allow for the wait to sit and have a bite with tea at the small eatery and read any informational signs along the paths or to simply stand and watch the birds and koi. You may also wish to stop and contemplate the designs in the sand at the zen? garden {my apologies for not being sure of the name} but I did stop and sit on the bench there and just .... sit. It was fun to go up onto the bridge and take a photo. Do take care - the climb is short but rather vertical.
Show less

If you are in the habit of visiting major gardens then you might find this one a little underwhelming with the exception of the buildings etc. The plants are interesting and some beautiful specimens. However if you are after flower colour, then there is little at this time of year. The entry price is $9 which is a little steep for what is on offer; it is 50% more than residents are charged, $6 is about right. It is a shame that the garden feels it needs to “fleece” tourists, but that is often the way of the world these days
Show less

The beautiful Japanese gardens and structures transports you to the asian country- very peaceful, clean and worth the visit. Went there around 10am so was not too crowded. Did not try the food though but had a great experience.

Being raised in San Francisco, the Japanese Tea Garden has been my favorite 'go to' spot for beauty and inspiration. The garden is immaculately groomed and maintained, and a local reminder of the beautiful gardens I saw when visiting Japan. The garden is definitely worth visiting.
Show less

The Tea Garden is really beautiful. Could be really serene too but we made the mistake of a Sunday visit and it was overrun with people. That being said we still enjoyed it immensely. Had a yummy snack in the tea house overlooking one of the Koi pools. Take some time to read the history of some of the original Bonsai trees, very interesting.
Show less
A beautiful garden to explore and enjoy

I loved this garden. Everything is beautifully manicured and maintained. Lots of peaceful rest spots to sit and enjoy the garden. After walking through the garden we enjoyed the lovely giftshop and stopping for tea and cookies overlooking the garden. The small fee was worth paying. The garden is easily found in the golden gate park by walking, biking or by car.
Show less
Great place for a green tea
Get there early on Mondays for free admission. The gardens are small but beautiful. Try the green tea with fortune cookies.

When in San Francisco, we always make time for a walk in the Garden and tea in the Teahouse. It is a beautiful and calm oasis in the city for a slow walk to notice all the sights and sounds of nature. The Teahouse has a good tea selection and tasty tea sandwiches and cookies. I always stop by the gift shop for a few fun trinkets or stocking stuffers like the panda head chopsticks for kids. A very short walk from the Academy of Science and the DeYoung Museum.
Show less
Lives up to its international reputation. Amazing plants. The teas and snacks are worth trying. Take your time here.
Quick place to check out the gardens

It was $9 per adult and took about 30 mins to walk through. It was cool to see the gardens but I wouldn't travel all the way to golden gate park to see it. Worth checking out if you're in the area though.

Wonderfully relaxing. A gentle walk through beautiful garden landscaped with pond, waterfalls, lush plants. The tea shop was very nice. I had the jasmine tea, edamame and tea cookies for under fifteen dollars. Note: there is admission fee. I would go again.
A beautiful place to go to, particularly on a sunny day, as I enjoyed a week ago. Delightfully set out. Allow yourself time to amble and absorb. Recommended.
Exotic Settings for Your Family Photos

At about 0845 on Sunday, 9/10/17, we arrived at the junction of 10th Ave and Fulton St. and found 3-4 free parking spots on Fulton. On weekdays there is free parking along Kennedy Drive. The Music Concourse Garage underground near the De Young Museum charges $5/hr. ($29 max.) weekdays and $6/hr. ($33 max.) weekends. It took only about 7 minutes to walk 0.3 mi. from our car, past the front of the De Young Museum, and on to the Tea Garden a short distance away. The garden opens at 0900. Early morning was a delightful time to stroll through the gardens. The air was cool, there was plenty of shade and no crowds. We loved the adventure of exploring the paths and being delighted at the sights appearing around each bend. The exotic settings provide great places for photos of family or friends or for just enjoying their serenity and beauty. See photos. We topped off the experience by delighting in tea & pancakes w/beans and Green Tea Cheesecake ($18.50 w/tip) at the Tea House. The gardens can easily be seen in one hour. Restrooms and gift shop are near the entrance.
Did this review earn a “Thankful" vote?
Show less

We visited the Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate Perk in early October, not exactly it's best season. Yet, it was truly beautiful, with gentle displays of water and statues linked by peaceful paths. When you need a respite from the frenetic atmosphere in much of San Francisco, this is the place.
Show less
nice little garden to visit, well design and very typical style. offered free tour by city, and free if you get in before 10 on Thursday (check their web site to make sure).

We made the trip to Golden Gatufe park specifically to visited the Japanese Gardens. It costs $9 for adults which I assume goes to the upkeep of the gardens. A beautiful tranquil spot perfect for some quiet time away from the hustle and bustle of the city.
Show less

It was my first time to visit the place and while it is just a small garden, it is well-maintained. The plants and trees are well-trimmed, clear water runs through the pond and the whole area clean. There is a small restaurant inside the garden but I didn’t get to try it. Overall, the garden offers a refreshing respite from the busy city.
Show less
The garden is small but worth the visit. Nicely done and peaceful. They offer tea and small plates which were fresh and delicious. Admission is reasonable.

Very peaceful and relaxing part of Golden Gate Park. Worth to visit for $9, I think it's free Monday/Wednesday/Friday before 10am. Takes about 30min to walk around, it has a coffee shop and a gift shop.
Reminded us of our time in Japan
Although a little expensive, we enjoyed this very much . . . definitely reminded us of the years we spent in Japan.

The Gardens are great and they put a lot of manual work into keeping them just as they were. They are small but there is much history and I recommend you take a guided tour. I happened upon one so I was lucky and got much more out of the trip than if I had just done it alone. There few signs telling you anything. so the tour guide is worth their weight in that regard. The Tea House was nice and the tea was just OK, nothing special like the the Tea House in the Chinese Garden in Portland Oregon. Now the reason I titled my review as I did, the front gate attendant that sells the tickets to the garden was just rude. His comments to visitors and remarks to his coworker were for his own private amusement and he has no business greeting people. He certainly did not help visitors over come the 9 dollar admission fee.
Show less
Visit was short, it's a beautiful garden
It's very nice to visit if you are around Golden Gate Park, for some Japanese heritage. Really nice to spend sometime at.

This lovely, peaceful garden is resplendent with manicured shrubs, winding paths, pools of Koi, Asian statues, and a tea house. The gardens are best when the cherry trees are in blossom. The garden is open from9am-6pm daily. Arrive before 10 am on Monday, Wednesday or Friday and admission is free, otherwise it is $9 for adults, $7 for seniors and youth. There is a tea house which is a bit pricy but serves tea and light snacks as you enjoy the relaxing views.
The Japanese Tea Garden dates to the 1894 Midwinter Expositon, a world fair attended by two million people and held in Golden Gate Park in San Francisco. The Japanese landscape designer, Hagiwara, lived with his family in the garden for years and assumed the personal responsibility for development and maintenance of the site until the Second World War when the family was relocated to internment camps in central California. Just a short walk to the de Young Museum and the Academy of Sciences.
Show less
Amazing garden This is really lovely I loved it An escape from city to the japanese nature You will love it

My husband and I loved this little oasis away from the hussle and bussle of the city. It was absolutely beautiful and the serene setting really helps you take a few moments and deep breaths to help calm and rejuvenate the mind.

After you visit the de Young museum in SF, make sure to stop by the Japanese Tea Garden...literally 100 yards from the museum. Not very large but exquisitely executed...perfect landscaping organized with an eye to serenity and composition. You'll feel like you've been transported to Kyoto...if only for a little while.

Really lovely place to wander around. We didn't have tea but enjoyed a stroll around the gardens. Really relaxing place.
It was O.K. But I expected there to be more of a traditional tea service, rather than , cough up the money and get a herbal tea served in a plastic cup!

My wife and I spent the day walking thru Haight - Ashbury and Golden Gate Park.

The Park has many signs to help navigate this expansive and beautiful section of San Francisco.
We plan to return and tour of the Botanical Gardens later this week. What a beautiful and well maintained Park!
Show less

This place is really pretty. It was $9 to get in and given how small it is, I think that's a bit steep. It took me maybe 15 or 20 minutes to slowly walk the whole garden. It's very well kept and you'll get some really pretty photos.
Show less
Very small park and nothing much to do

Based on the amount they charged for entry, there is nothing much to do here. I was able to complete the park within 10-15 mins. The park is maintained nicely and there were few photo opportunities but for the amount charged, I cannot suggest it.
It's so pretty here. Very serene and peaceful. Try to come earlier in the day as it might be a little quieter.
9$ wasted, more like a tourist trap, said it would take 25 mins, took more like 10-15mins. It was nice but could be better maintained.
Lovely garden. Smaller then we expected

Well worth a visit, but (probably smaller then one might expect and therefore quite costly for the time you will be there). A nice contrast to the other Golden Gate attractions (Museum of Sciences and De Young). Good visitors shop with some nice giftware. Serenity of the gardens slightly encroached upon by 'guided tours' getting in the way.
Show less

I had just visited the Fort Worth Japanese Tea Garden back in May which was so amazing, I was expecting this one to be even better but I have to say it wasn't. For the same $9.00 admission price the garden was not as big, not as nicely manicured and clean as the one in Fort Worth. It still was a nice visit, just not what I expected.
Show less
A Visit to Golden Gate Park

Called in here during our visit, it's not a huge garden but it's so interesting and pretty. Didn't try any of the tea or miso soup etc but just had an amazing time walking round it. Would thoroughly recommend a visit if you are in the area.
Show less
Take your time and stroll around. It is a small area so even with a few other tourists it was hard to get pictures without strangers in them. Have a snack at the tea house.
Enjoyed strolling along the paths and admiring the plants, structures, statues, and over-all tranquil atmosphere.

This would have to be the best Japanese gardens we have visited in the world (outside of Japan). The areas (rooms) of gardens were beautifully throughout with excellent use of colour, texture and shapes of foliage.
You have to pay to enter!
We didn't bother going in. It's a garden and you have to pay extra to look around it. We had already paid a load that day for Cal Academy.
Had a visit around this beautiful setting . $9 each to get in but free Friday morning between 9 and 10 am . Plenty of places to sit and contemplate. Japanese tea and food available and little shop .
Pretty place and worth the entrance fee. You only need a couple of hours here. There is a restaurant for a snack and drink.

The Japanese Tea Garden is beautifully designed and realised to the point I almost felt like I was back in Japan in one of the magnificent Gardens of Kyoto. Tranquil and calming, for just USD $8 it is well worth your time. Follow the signs around Golden Gate Park closely as the Garden entrance is a bit hard to find. You will leave in awe of the artistry on display.
Show less
This is the second time we have visited here. It's beautiful and no matter how many people are here, It's always very peaceful. The cafe is a little over priced but the drinks are lovely

This is an absolutely beautiful place to visit.. To many beautiful things to mention... trust me if you are close don't miss the opportunity to enjoy something you will never forget .. breathtaking !!!
You can feel a breeze of Kyoto

Japan has the art of doing everything with philosophy and a thorough ritual. Each garden has it's own story telling. There can only be admiration for the work they do to make a garden beautiful and in harmony with all that surrounds it. This place is a peace of Kyoto in San Francisco. You can hear the whisper of tradition touching your skin.
Show less
A beautiful little garden stroll. Very relaxing and serene. There is a small charge to get in, it's not free like other parts of Golden Gate Park, but for a few bucks it's worth it.

The Japanese Tea Garden is somewhere in the middle of Golden Gate Park. We cycled there as part of a day out on our bikes. I hadn't realised you had to pay to go in which I was a bit disappointed about, however we chose to go in, at $9 dollars each I think. You can wander around the gardens at your leisure and it was very pretty. We had some food at the cafe and chose some unusual Tea and I have the dish with noodles which was very tasty. In terms of value for money probably a little over priced, but still glad we went. If you've plenty of time and can fit it in then I would say it's worth a visit, but I wouldn't put it at the top of your list.
Show less

The Japanese Tea Garden was near the top of our list of places to visit in San Francisco, and it did not disappoint. It was a relaxing retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city, with a multitude of photographic opportunities. Very, very nice!

One of the extra's inside Golden Gate Park. This isn't far from the main area, but there is an extra fee to get in. I think it's a bit inflated, but people still come.
The gardens are well maintained and there are different visual points to visit.
This is a beautiful place with unique area's. They have rock/stone bridge and waterfalls.
Its not very big, but still quite enjoyable.
Show less
Although the Tea leaves something to be desired, the trees, shrubs and ponds were all beautifully groomed.
The Oldest Public Japanese Garden in the United States
Truly enjoyed walking along its paths and ponds, enjoying the sights of the Tea House, Pagoda and bridges. Relaxing landscape.
Quiet nice but not worth 9$ pp
Is quiet a nice place but very small. For the entrance fee of 9$ one expect a bit more than the offered.

This place is very quiet and serene. You can even sit and get tea here to enjoy.. There are some buddas and a temple to look at. A big coy pond with huge fish also. Great picture taking spot. It was one of the stops we could get off on the tour bus..
Show less
Such a great spot, before the crowds really arrive. If you get there between 9am-10am it's free entry. The zen garden towards the back of the property was extremely peaceful.
A very well maintained garden. A bit too small but its really a replica of what a tea garden would look like. A little pricey for entrance fees. Worth the visit.

We visited the park on Wednesday. As it was after 10am, there was an entrance fees. The layout of the park was well planned, every corner was nice. We enjoyed the ponds, the waterfalls and the bonzi trees very much. But we noticed the water in the ponds was not so clear not sure they were good for the fishes.
Show less

After seeing a beautiful picture or two, I had it in mind that I wanted to go here the next time we visited San Francisco. It was exceptionally annoying getting here due to it being Labor Day weekend, so some of our disappointment had to do with the crowds, traffic, and parking, rather then the garden itself. The parking garage is absolutely ludicrous, with only one exit yet signs pointing like there's other ways to exit, and we must've waited 30 minutes to exit. The garden itself is pretty, but very small and much smaller than other similar gardens we have we have visited (such as Morikami). That said, $9 a person is not a high entrance fee; however can't imagine spending more than 30 minutes here and would certainly never seek it out again if not right in the general vicinity already.
Show less
Worth any effort to find, in one area of Golden Gate Park

The walk through the garden is joyful. The layout, the twists and turns, suprises around every corner. The water features, the bridges, volunteers maintaining the stunning trees and plants. The reward before you leave is the tea room, drinking tea and tasting the wonderful tiny pastries. peaceful, tranquil,relaxing.
Show less

Not sure whether to review this as an attraction or a restaurant. My wife is disabled and though they don't have special prices for such they only charged for my young daughter - not even for me, the wheelchair pusher. Very generous! We started with tea. It's nothing fancy but it's a great experience. A pot of Sencha tea, Udon noodles, tea sandwiches, edamame and Dorayaki made for an interesting and surprisingly tasty snack at a very reasonable price. Order at the outdoor counter and eat under the gazebo-like shelter. Service was quick.

The gardens themselves were scenic and had some interesting water features/stepping stones. It is quite hilly and some places were a bit of a challenge when pushing the wheelchair but on the whole it was wheelchair accessible with some minor detours.
Show less

At $9 entrance it's cheap by SF standards and probably an hour is long enough for a walk around and a tea. Picturesque - well tended and tranquil. If you like wildlife, you may be lucky and see the hummingbirds.

We randomly went to Golden Gate Park and stumbled upon the Tea Gardens. We weren't aware that there was a fee to enter, however we are glad we paid and went into the park. The gardens, pagoda, bridges, and buidling were all beautiful. It was very tranquil. There is food and tea available. This was a very nice surprise within the park.
Show less
I'm there whit my friend. The garden is very small. Nice to see but very expensive. Into the garden you can taste japan tea but is expensive too.
You need to pay to visit the garden and in my view, it is not worth it! The entrance fees is way too high for the experience.
Loved the gardens, the tea aspect was disappointing

The Japanese garden is lovely, beautifully manicured with formal and less formal areas. The winding paths, little waterfalls, stepping stones and bridges are charming, balanced beautifully with historical pagodas and gates. Some mighty big carp in the ponds as well!
The tea room was pokey, with little choice in the way of food- it being largely premade and prepackaged. The teas on offer were also limited, in all, very unappetising and quite disappointing.
Show less
Nice stop on otherwise busy day
My daughter and I stopped into the Japanese Garden on our trip to San Francisco and it was lovely. Would definitely go back
Free tour from San Francisco Library

The Japanese Tea Garden is a paid attraction. There are scheduled tours provided by the San Francisco Library (check their website for times and dates) which give you a much better appreciation for the experience.
Beautiful gardens, immaculately kept. The tea cafe is perfect - tea and cookies are delicious! The best time to go is in the afternoon, since the gardens are small and can get crowded.
This garden is part of Golden Gate Park. This place is really amazing. You can feel that you are in Japan. The entrance is not free. Max stay - around 1h
Beautiful Spot in Golden Gate Park
Extremely popular garden in the center of Golden Gate Park, very well-maintained and much loved. A little overwhelmed by the visitors. Authentic.
Beautiful garden, very well maintained, mostly authentic.

Kinda touristy, particularly that kiddy bridge in the photo. Most of it was authentic to the gardens I visited in Kyoto and Tokyo but some things look to be Americanized a bit. Healthy plants, nice Coy pond. Restrooms, cafe.

Japanese Tea Garden is located in Golden Gate Park.
Once inside it is as if you were in Japan. The Garden is marvelous and peaceful. It is not that big but you could spend hours contemplating it.
Check their site as there are free entrances during weekdays before 10 am.
Show less

Agree with many of the previous reviews, the entrance fee is a little high given the size of the gardens. However we found the gardens tranquil and picturesque and a photographers delight. It was quite an over cast day on the day we visited and yet the colours of the garden were just stunning.
Show less

A beautiful place of serenity and peace in the hubbub of The City. Doesn't take very long to walk through, and has a gift shop and small restaurant. $9 for entry so it's a bit high but maybe not for San Fran.
The gardens are absolutely breathtaking. Every direction you turn is something beautiful. The bridges and pagodas were my favorite. Definitely worth the 9.00 admission.
Visit this park within a park for a photographer's paradise; Small but peaceful and beautiful

This is one of my favorite places to visit in SF. Golden Gate park can be so large to visit it is difficult to know where to start or what to see. This small park within a park is one place you should see. You can park along the streets near the entry and you walk up and pay to enter at one of the large wooden doors. Once inside, you can walk clockwise or counterclockwise around in a circle to view the wonderful Japanese gardens. There is also a small tea restaurant and place to sit and sip tea in the center of the gardens. It closes at 6 pm most days. My favorite area is the large pond and the bridges in and around the pond. Parts of the pond are sunken, there are koi to watch, there is a waterfall and there is one arching bridge that kids can clamber up for photos. All of it is gracefully presented. It is a photographer's paradise.
Show less
The Japanes Tea Garden is fine experience. Beautifully kept gardens and a wonderful tea house make for a great experience.
One of the cheaper things to do in Golden Gate Park. Unfortunately everything costs a lot but this was worth the $9 entry fee. You feel like you step into a different world.

The entry fee advertised is or residents so expect to pay more for tourists. A very pretty but busy garden. The tea shop served nice tea, cakes and savoury dishes. Doesn't take long to walk around but there was a bit of a queue to get in. We went on a Saturday though.
Show less
Visite décevante pour un prix élevé
It's a very little garden for an expensive price. We spent 20min for 9$ per person!! It's a nice place but there are a lot of free Japanese gardens in others countries larger and as kind as this one.
There is a distinct taste of the difference between Japanese sweets and American sweets. It is quite an experience. Very quiet and peaceful. Try the Matcha!

We took advantage of free admission hours, which in our case was relatively early Friday morning. This worked to our advantage because it was not crowded when we entered. It is a place where you can stroll around to various enclaves and appreciate different arrangements of landscaping and garden art, including statues, pagodas, etc. There is small cafe and a gift shop nearby. At the cafe, we ordered a pot of tea for two, and there is also a small food menu. Convenient if you are planning to visit Golden Gate Park.
Show less
A pretty, enclosed garden in contrast to the wider areas of the park. Probably more peaceful in low tourist seasons but a calm corner nonetheless.
Relax in the heart of San Francisco

This is a wonderful place. Every time that we come to the city we stop in at the garden. It iw worth the price of admission to walk around and see the wonderful job that the gardeners have down to make an oasis in the park. In the middle of this is the Tea garden. We ordered a pot of tea and some cookies and relaxed while gazing at the grounds. I definitely recommend this for all traveller to the area. Enjoy.
Show less

The Japanese Tea Garden can be a little escape from the noise of the city. I took a visit here while traveling for work, just to decompress. It is picturesque and provides plenty of space throughout the park to sit and contemplate. There is also a cafe where you can sit have authentic Japanese teas. I had the best cup of jasmine!
Show less

In my humble opinion one of the best gardens to visit. Beautifully manicured gardens and ponds. A authentic Tea house with a variety of goodies such as miso, udon and tea sandwiches along with some hot tea choices. Tea house gets crowded around lunchtime, go early or wait until after 2pm. Worth the time to sit and sip tea! Gift shop has nice items but a bit pricey.
Show less
We had a great weather day and the garden was nice. Much smaller than I thought but I thoroughly enjoyed the Mochi Ice Cream at the small snack area.

The Japanese Tea Garden could be a charming, sensual experience but for the crowds that visiting the site feel like just another compressed urban experience. The narrow paths through the garden were crowded and loud, stripping the garden of its intended purpose. The tea and tastings were fine, but the hustle of the dining area reduced the experience to nice warm tea and satisfactory bites. We visited early on a Friday and it was a mob scene; we strongly recommend mid-week.
Show less
This is so peaceful here after the hassle and bustle of San Francisco. Just wander around and enjoy the water, plants and garden in general. Beautiful.
A Bit Pricy, But Worth It

Although when first entering these gardens it might seem to be a little bit pricey for this small an area, considering today's prices, it seemed reasonable to my husband and me. Japanese gardens portray more water and building than other types of gardens and there is a bit of history that would be worthwhile reading along the way. I would recommend seeing these gardens at least once.
Show less
Flowers, trees, bridges, shrines, ponds, fish. Beautiful and serene. Don't skip over seeing the gardens while you're in the city.

The Japanese Tea Garden is lovely. Paths wind through gingko and Japanese maple trees, hydrangeas and other flowers were blooming in early August, and the sculpture and ponds with koi were lovely. There were quite a few people there when we were, on a Sunday, but it didn't feel crowded or overwhelming.
Show less

This is one of my two ALL TIME favorite places in SF. An oasis of serenity and beauty tucked inside the park. For me, this is required if I am to set foot in the city. Take a time out and relax/enjoy the calm for a bit. You will not regret it!
Show less

Entrance fee was free before 10am in the day we want there. The garden layout is beautiful with an enchanting view with every twist and turn on the winding paths. Some of the pagodas are clearly in need of maintenance - you can see the peeling paint and fading colors. The gift shop and the tea shop by the pond were delightful (albeit expensive) as well. Totally worth a visit.
Show less

Beautifully laid out gardens with a tea room. We stopped for some Japanese tea of which there was plenty of choice. We went very early in the day, so, it wasn't too busy, but, as we left it was getting busier.
Hidden gem, had no idea this beautiful park and tea garden existed. Beautifully laid out, peaceful atmosphere and overall a lovely experience.

My friend told me not to miss this site. She told me the history of the original owner and it had made me feel so sad. But the beauty of this garden is overwhelming. Each part is carefully designed and well kept. It is very quiet in the garden. I could have taken a book and sat under a tree all day.
There is a place to get tea at the end of the trail, but I did not want any. There are also bathrooms. I would think if you had small children, this is not the place to view it as a jungle gym. It is a place of some very old pieces.
Show less

This Japanese garden is a beautiful horticulture gem in Golden Gate Park. The garden's current size is approximately 5 acres. There are classic Japanese elements such as an arched drum bridge, pagodas, stone lanterns, stepping stone paths, native Japanese plants, serene koi ponds and a zen garden. Cherry blossom trees bloom throughout the garden in March and April.
Show less
it was a gloomy day yet the surroundings are beautiful in japanese style. Nice bamboo plants and cute bridges.

The garden has beautiful Japanese plants & features such as koi fish ponds, pagodas & Buddha statue. It's small & beautifully formed. We enjoyed jasmine & green tea and a tasty selection of cookies at a reasonable price. The visit was spoilt somewhat by too many people to be peaceful, and rather shabby buildings.
Show less

We stumbled on this tea garden quite by accident looking for somewhere to fly a drone. It was amazing! Beautifully landscaped, it was a lovely place to take a stroll and take in the beautiful garden. Truly a hidden gem!

We visited before 10:00 am on a Friday, and admission is free at that time. It was a wonderful and quick stop before our trip to the California Academy of Sciences. By 10, the Japanese Tea Garden was already quite crowded, however, we were able to enjoy it thoroughly. Just beautiful!
Show less

The Japanese Tea Garden is well worth a visit. It is full of beautiful plants, features and ponds with little bridges and stepping stones. Large carp swin in the ponds which are lovely to watch.

Only negatives are: it's quite a small area and the $9 price tag seems a bit steep. However, it's free between 9.00-10.00 am (check if that's only certain days). Also, it gets extremely busy - so going early would probably solve this. Another side more: toilets aren't great. Much better to visit the toilets near the bowling green area - loads of well looked after cubicles (lol).

But I think most people who enjoy looking around gardens will enjoy this one.
Show less
Go early or late or on a weekday

Loved it. So many interesting features. I went when it rained and it was beautiful and most of the people went to the teahouse so I had a lot of the garden to myself. It got crowded once it stopped raining - this was on a Friday in August. Probably not so busy a at the start of the day or end and not during the height of tourist season. Easily worth the $9; next time I will go at a less busy time and enjoy some matcha or soup.
Show less

After hours in the de Young a shared cup of tea and macha cheesecake in the Japanese Garden followed by a stroll around the gardens was a perfect ending to a great day. The gardens were tranquil with lots of green plants, ponds, a giant budda, and temple structures. The garden fills one with serenity and peace.
Show less
Amazing beauty in a compact space. The garden is beautiful, though a bit crowded on a nice day. It was great to walk around the garden and to enjoy a cup of tea.
Lovely garden well worth a visit tranquil place well kept,good shop and tearoom plants lovely colors

This is such a beautiful spot and we thought it was worth the admission fee ($9 per person). It was a bit crowded, but if you're patient, there are pockets of time when the crowd dissipates and you can truly take in the beauty and relish in the peacefulness.
Show less
An oasis in a hot city

Japanese Tea Garden is a very beautiful garden. We were there in mid-June, which is not the peak tourist season. So the place was not too crowded. There was time to enjoy the garden and the buildings.
- Be prepared for a long walk, as there is no parking close by. Depending on your luck, you might need walk from half a mile to a mile. But the rest of the Golden Gate Park is beautiful, too, so enjoy the walk.
Show less
Spent $18 to go in to enjoy the Japanese gardens. Very pretty but too crowded to really enjoy. I should have skipped it.
The Japanese tea garden was in my top 2 things to do in SF. I wish that we had more time to spend and relax here. Many beautiful scenes. Many great photo opportunities. I wish I had more time.
